# Pre-Course Survey: Background, Experience, and Scientific Reasoning

title: Idea collection
text:
Warm-Up & Background

W1. What is your primary field of study (major)?
(Short text)
W2. Do you have a secondary field of study (minor)?
(Short text or ‚ÄúNone‚Äù)
W3. Which semester of your Bachelor‚Äôs program are you currently in?
(Single choice)

3rd semester

4th semester

5th semester

6th semester

Other / extended program

W4. Have you taken a quantitative methods or statistics course before?
(Single choice)

No

Yes, one course

Yes, more than one course


W5. Why did you register for this class?
(Multiple choice ‚Äî pick all that apply üòé)

My degree says I have to (mandatory course)

My degree says I should take something like this (elective)

I‚Äôm here voluntarily ‚Äî I actually want to learn quantitative methods

I optimized my schedule and this was the least painful option

I heard the professor is cool / the class is fun

I was curious and just decided to give it a shot
W6. Which statement best describes how you feel about quantitative methods right now?
(Single choice)

Curious and motivated

Neutral

Slightly nervous

Very nervous

Actively avoiding thinking about it üòÖ

title: Idea collection
text:
Section A ‚Äî Technical Experience & Tools

A1. Which of the following tools have you heard of before?
(Multiple selection)

R

RStudio / Positron

Quarto / R Markdown

Git

GitHub

Python

Stata

SPSS

Excel (advanced use beyond basic spreadsheets)

LaTeX

Command line / terminal

A2. Which of the following tools have you actively worked with before?
(Multiple selection)

R

RStudio / Positron

Quarto / R Markdown

Git

GitHub

Python

Stata

SPSS

Excel

LaTeX

Command line / terminal

None of the above

A3. How would you describe your overall confidence in working with code?
(Single choice)

Very low ‚Äì I find code intimidating

Low ‚Äì I can follow examples but struggle independently

Medium ‚Äì I can modify existing code and troubleshoot basic issues

High ‚Äì I can write code for my own analyses

Very high ‚Äì I regularly work with code-based projects

title: Idea collection
text:
Section B ‚Äî Scientific Reasoning & Inference

B1. Please indicate how much you agree or disagree with the following statements:
(Likert scale: strongly disagree ‚Üí strongly agree)

Statistical analysis is mainly about determining whether a hypothesis is true or false.

Empirical data can increase or decrease our confidence in a theoretical claim.

Uncertainty should be explicitly reported when presenting empirical results.

Scientific knowledge is always provisional and subject to revision with new data.

A single statistical result can definitively prove or disprove a theory.

Models are simplifications of reality rather than exact representations.

B2. When you see a numerical result in a paper (e.g., an estimate or coefficient), what are you usually most interested in?
(Select up to two)

Whether it is ‚Äústatistically significant‚Äù

The size of the effect

The uncertainty around the estimate

Whether the result fits the theory

Whether the model assumptions seem plausible

I am usually unsure how to interpret such results

title: Idea collection
section: Section C ‚Äî Modeling & Data Analysis Experience
text:
Section C ‚Äî Modeling & Data Analysis Experience

C1. Which of the following methods or analyses have you heard of?
(Multiple selection)

Descriptive statistics
Correlation analysis

Linear regression

Multivariate regression

Logistic regression

Interaction effects

Panel data / fixed effects

Multilevel / mixed-effects models

Causal diagrams (DAGs)

Simulation / Monte Carlo methods

C2. Which of the following have you actively applied yourself (e.g., in assignments, term papers, or projects)?
(Multiple selection)

Descriptive statistics
Correlation analysis

Linear regression

Multivariate regression

Logistic regression

Interaction effects

Panel data / fixed effects

Multilevel / mixed-effects models

Causal diagrams (DAGs)

Simulation / Monte Carlo methods

None of the above

C3. In previous coursework, data analysis was mostly‚Ä¶
(Single choice)

Interpreting outputs produced by others

Following step-by-step instructions

Applying methods to my own research questions

Designing and executing a full analysis independently
